t: Proverbs 20
Wine*pn is a mocker and beer a brawler; whoever*ld is led astray by them is not wise.
A*pn king’s wrath strikes terror like the roar of a lion; those*ld who anger him forfeit their lives.
It*pn is to one’s honor to avoid strife, but*ld every fool is quick to quarrel.
Sluggards*pn do not plow in season; so*ld at harvest time they look but find nothing.
The*pn purposes of a person’s heart are deep waters, but*ld one who has insight draws them out.
Many*pn claim to have unfailing love, but*ld a faithful person who can find?
The*pn righteous lead blameless lives; blessed*ld are their children after them.
When*pn a king sits on his throne to judge, he*ld winnows out all evil with his eyes.
Who*pn can say, “I have kept my heart pure; I*ld am clean and without sin”?
Differing*pn weights and differing measures— the*ld Lord*s detests them both.
Even*pn small children are known by their actions, so*ld is their conduct really pure and upright?
Ears*pn that hear and eyes that see— the*ld Lord*s has made them both.
Do*pn not love sleep or you will grow poor; stay*ld awake and you will have food to spare.
“It’s*pn no good, it’s no good!” says the buyer— then*ld goes off and boasts about the purchase.
Gold*pn there is, and rubies in abundance, but*ld lips that speak knowledge are a rare jewel.
Take*pn the garment of one who puts up security for a stranger; hold*ld it in pledge if it is done for an outsider.
Food*pn gained by fraud tastes sweet, but*ld one ends up with a mouth full of gravel.
Plans*pn are established by seeking advice; so*ld if you wage war, obtain guidance.
A*pn gossip betrays a confidence; so*ld avoid anyone who talks too much.
If*pn someone curses their father or mother, their*ld lamp will be snuffed out in pitch darkness.
An*pn inheritance claimed too soon will*ld not be blessed at the end.
Do*pn not say, “I’ll pay you back for this wrong!” Wait*ld for the Lord,*s and he will avenge you.
The*pn Lord*s detests differing weights, and*ld dishonest scales do not please him.
A*pn person’s steps are directed by the Lord.*s How*ld then can anyone understand their own way?
It*pn is a trap to dedicate something rashly and*ld only later to consider one’s vows.
A*pn wise king winnows out the wicked; he*ld drives the threshing wheel over them.
The*pn human spirit is the lamp of the Lord*s that*ld sheds light on one’s inmost being.
Love*pn and faithfulness keep a king safe; through*ld love his throne is made secure.
The*pn glory of young men is their strength, gray*ld hair the splendor of the old.
Blows*pn and wounds scrub away evil, and*ld beatings purge the inmost being.
